sourceDesc.bibl: Cané, Miguel. "Esther. Novela original." Biblioteca Virtual Miguel de Cervantes, 2000, http://www.cervantesvirtual.com/obra-visor-din/esther-novela-original--0/html/.
Cané, Miguel. Esther. Novela original. Buenos Aires: Imprenta de Mayo, 1858. p. 25-105.

encodingDesc.p: The text was converted from an HTML source.
The spelling was checked and corrected where appropriate.

The following phenomena were marked up: front matter (where available, e.g. title page, dedication, preface, introduction), part and chapter divisions, headings, paragraphs, inserted texts (e.g. letters or newspaper articles), verse lines, dramatic text, quotations (e.g. epigraphs), notes by the author, and gaps.

p.quote: Eugenio Segry, proscripto de algún país sudamericano, se enamora de una bella inglesa, Esther, esposa de Lord Wilson y madre de Enrique. Un día él arriesga su vida por salvar a la mujer y al hijo tras el desbocamiento de sus caballos; en agradecimiento ella lo invita a conocer su casa y a su esposo. Juntos recorren centros artísticos florentinos y asisten a reuniones sociales, reflexionan sobre las sociedades italiana y argentina, se expresan su mutuo amor, hasta que Esther muere súbitamente, víctima de un aneurisma.
p.bibl: Molina, Hebe Beatriz (2011), Como crecen los hongos. La novela argentina entre 1838 y 1872, Buenos Aires: Teseo, p. 442-443.

p.quote: Esther is a little more than a pale reflection of French romantic models (it contains points of coincidence with Mme de Staël's Corinne), with a Byronic twist in the character and personality of the male protagonist. Eugenio Segry, an Argentine expatriate, has a love affair with Esther Wilson, an unhappily married English Lady, whose life is brought to an end while she and her lover are attending a performance of Lucia de Lamermoor. The story is set in Florence, where Eugenio and Esther spend some of the happiest moments of their lives in the ecstatic contemplation and lyrical commentary of the city's artistic treasures.
p.bibl: Castagnaro, Anthony R., The Early Spanish American Novel: p. 150. Cited by Lichtblau, Myron (1997), The Argentine Novel: an annotated bibliography, Lanham, Maryland, p. 171.

p.quote: Esther exemplifies Cané's literary creed of 'art for art's sake' and is in many respects an early manifestation of the 'modernista' novel cultivated at the turn of the century by his compatriots Enrique Larreta and Angel Estrada.
p.bibl: Lichtblau, Myron (1959), The Argentine novel in the nineteenth century, p. 73. Cited by Lichtblau, Myron (1997), The Argentine Novel: an annotated bibliography, Lanham, Maryland, p. 171.
